blocks.blockName: Hack @ UCI - A.R.T. Artist's Realtime Toolkit [Winter 2020]
paragraphs: My team's submission. The project for this hackathon was to create a tool for aspiring digital artists to more easily draw on their computers. Most digital artists day have to spend a lot of money on expensive drawing tablets, so we set out to lower the barrier of entry by allow users to use their phones to draw on their computers. We successfully made two iterations of the project.

The first is just a collaborative drawing app where strokes on canvas appear as strokes on another, linked together by a common ID. The second iteration is where a user's phone can act like a pointer on the screen and be used to draw like you're using a wiimote. (Simply change the mode on both the computer and phone to 'Pointer' to see it in action.
A demo of the project is available here.
Skills: Coffee/Tea/Monster/Gatorade(?)

BananaToken Arcade is my personal collection of HTML5 and Flash games that I've developed. I first made The website in 2014 and since then a small community has grown around it. The website has a custom user registration and login system run behind the scenes in a MySQL database. The backend is comprised of a mix of NodeJS and PHP.
The source code for the games is available here.
Skills: Javascript, jQuery, anime.js, HTML, CSS, PHP, SQL, MySQL Databases, HTML5, Phaser3, Flash (AS3)

The result fantastic and the experience enlightening.
The source code is here.

My team's submission for 2019's HackSC Hackathon. The concept is a VR mobile/desktop game where virtually interact and play with a dog. The app even includes voice commands to increase immersion. My team used Unity for the project, my role was as primary programmer (in C#).
My team won first place in two categories for this hack: the entertainment vertical (major category) and hacker's choice (most popular hack).
The source code for the hack is available here.
Skills: Unity, C#, Git, VR

blocks.blockName: Hack @ UCI - Abrupt Cow Chat [2019 Winter]
paragraphs: My team's submission for 2019's HackUCI Hackathon. The concept was simple, create something and submit it so we can get practice working in teams. We did just that and settled on an early internet style chat application. We also made a 90's style website to go along with it.
Github source available here.
Skills: Python, Nodejs, Google Cloud Services

We ended up creating a racing game where the goal is demolish as much stuff as you can, but you can only destroy things by drifting into them. It was grueling, but very rewarding and results looked great!
The source code for this game is no longer available to me.
